## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
'if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))
    install.packages("BiocManager")

BiocManager::install("GEOquery")'
library(GEOquery)
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
data = getGEO("GSE183030")
gse183030 = exprs (data[[1]])
gse183030<-data.frame(gse183030)
gse183030
write.csv(gse183030,file="gse183030")
gene<-fread("C:/Users/bless/OneDrive/MS_Studies/AML/assignment5/gse183030/GeneNames.txt")
gene<-data.frame(head(gene,154))
gene
gse183030<-cbind(Gene=gene$Name,gse183030)
gse183030

anno<-fread("C:/Users/bless/OneDrive/MS_Studies/AML/assignment5/GO_Annotated.csv")
#interact(anno$Gene_Symbol,gene$Name)
similar<-anno$Gene_Symbol[anno$Gene_Symbol %in% gene$Name]
write.csv(similar,file = "similar.csv")

matched_rows <- data.frame()

for (i in similar) {
  # Subset the data frame based on the condition
  matching_row <- subset(gse183030, Gene == i)
  
  # Check if any matching rows were found
  if (nrow(matching_row) > 0) {
    # Append the matching rows to the result data frame
    matched_rows <- rbind(matched_rows, matching_row)
  }
}
#write.csv(matched_rows,file="Match_gse.csv")
print(matched_rows)
```
